abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Kot Addu Combined
            Cycle Power Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The
            project was successful in meeting its objectives, its impact
            on institutional development was negligible, sustainability
            is likely, and both the Bank and Borrower performed
            satisfactorily. Two key lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the chances of technical problems affecting
            project implementation could have been reduced if
            WAPDA's technical staff assigned to the project had
            been able to perform their anticipated functions in a timely
            manner. The fact that these officials had to devote
            considerable time to routine administrative matters
            highlights the need for WAPDA to streamline its
            administrative procedures so as to more effectively utilize
            its technical manpower and resources. Second, the project
            highlights an issue arising from design changes during
            implementation. While the conversion to fuel oil firing
            probably saved on the direct cost of generation for this
            project, it has left the unanticipated problem of disposal
            of waste sludge, traffic congestion, and significantly
            higher plant maintenance costs. As these design changes were
            midstream events, they probably did not receive the level of
            scrutiny normally associated with project appraisal.
            Clearly, both the Bank and Borrower should review and agree
            on major modifications of the design only after all the
            associated costs (and benefits) have been identified and evaluated.
